<p><strong>Social mobility</strong> is a concept that considers peoples socioeconomic circumstances and the degree to which they change over a lifetime and across generations. This includes a consideration of whether a persons social and economic future is shaped by where they start in life. In a society with high social mobility, someone could, for example, be born to economically disadvantaged parents but still have the same likelihood of opportunities as someone born into a more prosperous home.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="21081d2d-17e5-4d96-bda2-5ebcc5d66852"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="21081d2d-17e5-4d96-bda2-5ebcc5d66852" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Individuals can be both upwardly and downwardly mobile. An individual may be considered downwardly mobile if their socioeconomic circumstances are less than those of their parents at the same age, or if their social and economic position drops relative to others. As a result, a highly mobile society could see some individuals being affected positively while others would be affected negatively. </span></span></span></a></span></p>
<!-- -->
<p>Businesses with strong environmental, social, and governance (ESG) motivations are increasingly looking at how they can promote diversity, equity, and inclusion as part of their S, or <em>social</em>, agenda.  However, socioeconomic diversity, which is directly linked to social mobility, is a diversity category that many businesses struggle to define and ultimately engage in. It is complex, dynamic, multidimensional, and contextual to a given country. It is also intersectional: socioeconomic factors can combine with gender, race, ethnicity, and other factors in a way that exacerbates the disadvantages experienced by people in those groups.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cff67b21-b3ce-41cd-bda5-d70478ece1b5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cff67b21-b3ce-41cd-bda5-d70478ece1b5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">See for example, Eleanor Bernardes et al., <em>Ethnicity, gender and social mobility</em>, Social Mobility Commission, December 28, 2016; and Lucinda Platt and Carolina Zuccotti, <em>Social mobility and ethnicity</em>, Institute for Fiscal Studies, June 29, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>This article will examine some of the economic and business benefits that companies can expect from helping to broaden the socioeconomic diversity of the talent pool in their organizations. Some of these benefits are macro at the economy level and can be measured: better social mobility can support economic growth through more effective deployment of talent. Others are micro at the company level and, given that socioeconomic data is currently hard to collect, can be inferred from broader data on diversity: research shows that organizations with higher rates of diversity in their workforce perform better for reasons that include being better able to attract top talent and improved customer orientation, employee satisfaction, and decision making.</p>
<p>Corporations now have a critical window of opportunity to reflect on socioeconomic diversity. Our research indicates that the current economic and societal shocks, such as the COVID-19 pandemic and the rapidly increasing cost of living, have affected socioeconomic disadvantages and social mobility, with knock-on effects for employees, candidates, suppliers, customers, and communities in real time. At the same time, many people management processes will need to be reconsidered in response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the economic headwinds, making this an opportune time for corporations to consider which actions they can take next.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4ca5a657-4bd2-430f-a22c-ac3360d09c3a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4ca5a657-4bd2-430f-a22c-ac3360d09c3a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="/featured-insights/future-of-work/the-future-of-work-after-covid-19">The future of work after COVID-19</a>, McKinsey Global Institute, February 18, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p>While social mobility is first and foremost influenced by public policy, corporations can also take actionand benefit from it. There are many interventions, but this article presents those in one area where companies could start: recruitment. </p>
<h2>Low social mobility comes at a cost to the economyand to individual companies</h2>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>The long-term impacts of socioeconomic disadvantage on individuals in the United Kingdom</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>The United Kingdoms social-mobility</strong> context has considerable complexity beyond what is explored in this article. What follows is a summary of existing data and research that may be useful context for businesses.</p>
<p>Evidence suggests that being born into a low-income family can affect many aspects of a persons later lifetheir health, their education, their earnings, and their childrens prospects across these same dimensions.</p>
<p>By the time individuals enter the workforce, they have already been significantly shaped by their socioeconomic backgrounds. Children born to parents with low incomes are more likely to experience poor nutrition, chronic disease, and mental-health problems throughout their lives as a consequence of their families being less able to provide them with healthy food, good-quality housing, adequate heating, or social and cultural opportunities.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="48c6a4cc-aab5-4045-a9ea-c151bf4cca38"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="48c6a4cc-aab5-4045-a9ea-c151bf4cca38" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Child poverty in Scotland: Health impact and health inequalities</em>, NHS Heath Scotland, 2018.</span></span></span></a></span> Children in lower-income neighborhoods are less likely to have access to highly rated schools, and the economically disadvantaged tend to do less well at school.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="dca8e4b4-a98f-4df3-bab7-13c4e51ae83f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="dca8e4b4-a98f-4df3-bab7-13c4e51ae83f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Avinash Akhal, Jo Hutchinson, and  Mary Ready, <em>Education in England: Annual report 2020</em>, Education Policy Institute, August 26, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Students from socioeconomically disadvantaged backgrounds are also more likely to drop out of university and less likely to achieve a first- or upper-second-class degree than those from more advantaged backgrounds.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f5bf5fa8-0265-4bf1-82f9-516512e8ff9a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f5bf5fa8-0265-4bf1-82f9-516512e8ff9a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Sue Hubble, Paul Bolton, and Joe Lewis, Equality of access and outcomes in higher education in England, House of Commons Library, June 2, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>As reported by the UK governments Social Mobility Commission, people of low-income upbringing are more likely to experience unemployment and more likely to remain in low-paid employment.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="75574c6a-0680-4eb7-a103-a7e8b84406a7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="75574c6a-0680-4eb7-a103-a7e8b84406a7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Learning ladders: The role of adult training in supporting progression from low pay</em>, Social Mobility Commission, November 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> A study by Sam Friedman and Daniel Laurison, sociology professors at the London School of Economics, found that those in high-status occupations whose parents were employed in semiroutine and routine jobs earned, on average, 6,200 a year less than colleagues in the same occupations, but whose parents had higher professional and managerial backgrounds. This remained the case even after controlling for a host of factors such as educational qualification, ethnicity, and different wage levels in different regions.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ff30b94e-93bc-47c3-9ee4-97b3d7255eec"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ff30b94e-93bc-47c3-9ee4-97b3d7255eec" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>British Politics and Policy</em>, Introducing the class ceiling, blog post by Sam Friedman and Daniel Laurison, March 31, 2015.</span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p>All ethnicities and genders can experience socioeconomic disadvantage, but socioeconomic disadvantages can also be compounded by ones gender and ethnicity.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fbe4a002-6e2d-49a1-940f-99ec12eb9421"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fbe4a002-6e2d-49a1-940f-99ec12eb9421" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Social mobility is a highly intersectional topic. Other aspects of experience including sexual orientation and disability are also likely to affect a persons opportunities to be socially mobile. See Kerith Conron, Shoshana  Goldberg, and Carolyn Halpern, Sexual orientation and sex differences in socioeconomic status: A population-based investigation in the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent to Adult Health, <em>Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health</em>, November 2018, Volume 72; Jouja Maamri and Daniel Dipper, No two journeys: Disability, Sutton Trust, January 19, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> For example, the Social Mobility Commissions 2016 report <em>Ethnicity, gender and social mobility</em> found that socioeconomically disadvantaged White British and White Other pupils were the lowest-performing groups at primary and secondary school and that Black children were the group most likely to grow up in poverty and one of the least likely groups to achieve a first- or upper-second-class degree at university.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="601f218d-6464-4889-82f9-ded8a3d8b6ff"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="601f218d-6464-4889-82f9-ded8a3d8b6ff" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Eleanor Bernardes et al., <em>Ethnicity, gender, and social mobility</em>, Social Mobility Commission, December 28, 2016.</span></span></span></a></span> When analyzed alongside dimensions such as gender and ethnicity, socioeconomic background can provide a deeper understanding of where disadvantage arises: for example, female students outnumber male students in higher education in the United Kingdom,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5ab646f8-8fe8-491e-9917-74d84bb01b42"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5ab646f8-8fe8-491e-9917-74d84bb01b42" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Rachel Hewitt, Mind the gap: Gender differences in higher education, Higher Education Policy Institute, March 7, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> yet government analysis shows that disadvantaged young women are the most likely group to choose post-16 technical courses which lead to lower paid jobs.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e85e939e-5e9e-4411-a876-b85f85b4f0e0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e85e939e-5e9e-4411-a876-b85f85b4f0e0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Disadvantaged women face pay penalty due to their subject choice, Social Mobility Commission press release, March 30, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Data suggests that perceptions of the United Kindoms level of social mobility are also shifting. According to a 2019 survey conducted by the Sutton Trust, a UK charity that works to promote social mobility,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3c6e17ef-0411-4f20-ac6d-1034b352b7e6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3c6e17ef-0411-4f20-ac6d-1034b352b7e6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey is one of four consultancy firms that have collaborated with the Sutton Trust to create a new Pathways to Consulting program to help improve socioeconomic diversity in the consulting workforce.</span></span></span></a></span> 35 percent of respondents agreed that people have equal opportunities to get ahead, a drop from 53 percent in 2008.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e9419699-f16a-4751-8449-1c07ce78855b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e9419699-f16a-4751-8449-1c07ce78855b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Social mobility polling 2019, Sutton Trust, November 20, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>There are ethical arguments for social mobility, but in this article we focus on the economic arguments. Social mobility affects both national economic performance and the financial performance of individual companies. Understanding the context and effects of social mobility is important for business leaders who wish to understand and maximize socioeconomic diversity in their own organizations (see sidebar The long-term impacts of socioeconomic disadvantage on individuals in the United Kingdom).</p>
<h3>The loss to the economy</h3>
<p>As an economic principle, the more efficient an economy is at matching job positions to those with the greatest potential to perform them well, the higher the economic output per person.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a025e2d1-66ee-45f5-8311-bfbedc3c8105"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a025e2d1-66ee-45f5-8311-bfbedc3c8105" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Mge Adalet McGowan and Dan Andrews, Labour market mismatch and labour productivity: Evidence from PIAAC data, OECD, April 28, 2015.</span></span></span></a></span> Low social mobility is therefore likely to affect both employment and productivity: those from a disadvantaged background may not have access to the opportunities to use their capabilities and skills to the fullest. This hampers value creation or, as the World Economic Forum noted in its 2020 report on global social mobility, Anything that undermines the best allocation of talent and impedes the accumulation of human capital may significantly hamper growth.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2f6ea40b-9e77-4d30-bdc2-252934e73537"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2f6ea40b-9e77-4d30-bdc2-252934e73537" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Global Social Mobility Index 2020: Why economies benefit from fixing inequality</em>, World Economic Forum, January 19, 2020. </span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Social mobility in the United Kingdom since 2020</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>Economic and societal shocks</strong> such as COVID-19 and the rapidly increasing cost of living can aggravate existing socioeconomic disadvantages and restrict social mobility.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7001320e-21f7-4f15-984e-fe3eb577db51"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7001320e-21f7-4f15-984e-fe3eb577db51" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jonathan Bridges, Georgina Green, and Mark Joy, Credit, crises, and inequality, Bank Underground, May 3, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> These conditions have knock-on effects for employees, candidates, suppliers, customers, and communities.</p>
<p>Two observations indicate that social mobility in the United Kingdom is likely to have worsened since the pandemic. First, data shows that those in lower socioeconomic groups were affected harder in areas such as health,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1a4d2af6-58f9-4a1f-b213-95c0d5c2620c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1a4d2af6-58f9-4a1f-b213-95c0d5c2620c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For example, analysis by the Office for National Statistics of deaths between March and April 2020, when the virus first had impact at scale, shows that those who died with a confirmed case of the SARS-CoV-2 virus were more likely to be economically disadvantaged. See <em>Disparities in the risk and outcomes of COVID-19</em>, Public Health England, August 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> employment,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a88f42f5-de29-4fbf-8f2a-8b2fe5ffb730"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a88f42f5-de29-4fbf-8f2a-8b2fe5ffb730" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For example, according to the Resolution Foundation, 18 percent of parents from the bottom quintile of income distribution lost a job between April 2020 and March 2021, almost double the rate among parents in the rest of the population. See Andrew Eyles, S<em>ocial mobility in the time of COVID: Assessing the social mobility implications of COVID-19</em>, Economy 2030 Inquiry, December 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> and financial security<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e50db438-6909-420b-8e3a-8307928554e6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e50db438-6909-420b-8e3a-8307928554e6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For example, Resolution Foundation analysis found that poorer households were far more likely to have depleted their savings and increased their debt than higher-income groups during the first year of the pandemic. See Torsten Bell, The COVID certainty: More savings for the rich, more debt for the poor, Resolution Foundation, June 30, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> during the height of the pandemic and lockdowns. Education, a key enabler of social mobility, was interrupted at all levels, from nursery school through to university. On average, students globally are eight months behind where they would have been absent the pandemic.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4fe5d50d-951a-4f81-a861-b5ff48d85b94"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4fe5d50d-951a-4f81-a861-b5ff48d85b94" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="/industries/education/our-insights/how-covid-19-caused-a-global-learning-crisis">How COVID-19 caused a global learning crisis</a>, McKinsey, April 4, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> A Department for Education review in 2021 found that pupils in the United Kingdom from lower-income backgrounds suffered greater learning losses than those from higher-income families.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5a2e8cdd-1638-4caa-8adf-889433084112"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5a2e8cdd-1638-4caa-8adf-889433084112" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Understanding progress in the 2020/21 academic year</em>, Department for Education and Renaissance Learning, Education Policy Institute, October 2021. </span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Second, data shows that these same groups are likely to struggle in the economic environment that has existed since the pandemic. Current inflationary conditions are disproportionately affecting low-income households,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0b0354aa-f1d0-44c4-859d-d795f6cd9477"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0b0354aa-f1d0-44c4-859d-d795f6cd9477" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Molly Broome and Jack Leslie, <em>Arrears fears: The distribution of UK household wealth and the impact on families</em>, Resolution Foundation, July 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> and gas and electricity costs make up a much higher proportion of these households total expenditures.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cdf0ab33-2380-4620-9cfd-2d21e5cc430e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cdf0ab33-2380-4620-9cfd-2d21e5cc430e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Karl Handscomb and Jonathan Marshall, <em>Cutting back to keep warm</em>, Resolution Foundation, August 15, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> The Resolution Foundation, a think tank focused on improving the living standards of those with low to middle incomes in the United Kingdom, estimates that prior to the pandemic 1.3 million families had no savings to cope with unexpected expenses or rising costs. Since then, lower-income households were less likely to increase savings during the pandemic than higher-income ones and have fewer resources from which to rebuild in the current climate.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="53b4ca03-4f88-4d07-872a-7bdbfe040f0a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="53b4ca03-4f88-4d07-872a-7bdbfe040f0a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">1.3 million familiesincluding one-in-twelve poor familieshave no savings to cope with rising cost pressures or unexpected expenses, Resolution Foundation, July 17, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span>
</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The Sutton Trust, a UK charity that works to promote social mobility,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c1f7ed84-32d6-4140-b3d1-0ededac813c4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c1f7ed84-32d6-4140-b3d1-0ededac813c4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey is one of four consultancy firms that have collaborated with the Sutton Trust to create a new Pathways to Consulting program focused on improving socioeconomic diversity in the consulting workforce.</span></span></span></a></span> has put a figure on the economic impact of the United Kingdom having social-mobility levels that are lower than the regional average (exhibit). A 2017 study found that a modest increase in the United Kingdoms social mobility (to the average level across Western Europe) could be associated with about a 9 percent increase in GDP, equivalent to 2,620 per person, or 170 billion, to the UK economy annually (in 2016 prices).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4cef5a46-6738-4e62-9079-b74bf8d8408d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4cef5a46-6738-4e62-9079-b74bf8d8408d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Helen Jenkins et al., <em>Social mobility and economic success</em>, Sutton Trust and Oxera, July 2017. </span></span></span></a></span> The opportunity for the UK economy may have increased following the economic and societal shocks of COVID-19 and the rapidly increasing cost of living (see sidebar Social mobility in the United Kingdom since 2020).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit </span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/fixing%20the%20ladder%20how%20uk%20businesses%20benefit%20from%20better%20social%20mobility/svgz-fixingtheladder-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Catching up with Western Europes average social-mobility levels could mean a GDP increase of more than 2,600 per person for the UK economy." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/fixing%20the%20ladder%20how%20uk%20businesses%20benefit%20from%20better%20social%20mobility/svgz-fixingtheladder-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h3>The opportunity for companies</h3>
<p>Just as low social mobility can constrain economic growth as a result of inefficient talent allocation, so too could it constrain corporate performance. Like gender and ethnicity, it is a diversity issue, with significant intersectionality.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0862b3db-3ed1-415f-b3d9-5d64402d7aa2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0862b3db-3ed1-415f-b3d9-5d64402d7aa2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Vivian Hunt, Dennis Layton, and Sara Prince, <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/why-diversity-matters">Why diversity matters</a>, McKinsey, January 1, 2015.</span></span></span></a></span>  </p>
<p>McKinseys <em>Diversity wins</em> report showed a correlation between performance and diversity in companies around the world.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9b587355-d562-42ee-8c0a-5ed59c383cec"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9b587355-d562-42ee-8c0a-5ed59c383cec" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Sundiatu Dixon-Fyle, Kevin Dolan, Dame Vivian Hunt, and Sara Prince, <a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/diversity-wins-how-inclusion-matters">Diversity wins: How inclusion matters</a>, McKinsey, May 19, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Those in the top quartile in terms of gender diversity on executive teams were 25 percent more likely to earn above-average profits than those in the bottom quartile. In the case of ethnic and cultural diversity, this gap increased to 36 percent. </p>
<p><a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/why-diversity-matters">Our research</a> suggests that diverse companies may be able to outperform because they recruit from the widest pool of talent and, in doing so, improve customer orientation, employee satisfaction, and decision making, all of which lead to a virtuous cycle of better performance. Although there is still significant work to be done, data on gender and ethnicity has often been collected and monitored by many larger organizations for years, making it somewhat easier for companies to see where to take action on diversity on these dimensions. With socioeconomic diversity, however, the picture is more complex for three reasons. </p>
<p>First, there is no single indicator of an individuals socioeconomic background. Analysis may use one or multiple indicators, including the postcode where someone grew up, if they received free school meals, if they were the first generation in their family to go to university, or what the occupation of their parents or caregivers were when they were 14 years old. Each of these indicators has its advantages and limitations. Second, socioeconomic status is not binary. Everyone grows up somewhere on a scale from the most deprived through to the wealthiest. Finally, this information is private, and each individual would need to consent to sharing it. Not everyone wants to self-identify as coming from a certain socioeconomic background. Therefore, most organizations, no matter how much they desire to support social mobility, do not always have the base information to be able to understand or make decisions to broaden the socioeconomic level of their talent pool. These complexities notwithstanding, there is substantive evidence that a number of UK professions are far from being socioeconomically diverse based on a number of common socioeconomic diversity metrics.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="74bd0a69-7471-40be-a425-30e4d1fa417e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="74bd0a69-7471-40be-a425-30e4d1fa417e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Elitist Britain 2019: The educational backgrounds of Britains leading people</em>, Sutton Trust and Social Mobility Commission, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>This is where understanding the context of social mobility can help to identify opportunity areas. For example, socioeconomic background is one factor in educational achievement: children from economically disadvantaged families tend to do less well at school and have less access to highly rated institutions than children from more prosperous households.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="de2ba137-c1ea-460f-a915-91dddfef34dd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="de2ba137-c1ea-460f-a915-91dddfef34dd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Avinash Akhal, Jo Hutchinson, and  Mary Ready, <em>Education in England: Annual report 2020</em>, Education Policy Institute, August 26, 2020. </span></span></span></a></span> Positions and sectors that recruit primarily based on academic attainment are therefore less likely to be attuned to the nuances of socioeconomically diverse backgrounds, and in the search for talent, may be missing out on candidates who have high potential across other metrics.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c0b9cd80-9379-42da-bbe4-e86ce70b4aec"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c0b9cd80-9379-42da-bbe4-e86ce70b4aec" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For a discussion of socioeconomic diversity in leading UK roles, see <em>Elite Britain 2019</em>.</span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p>With many corporations reconsidering their people management processes in response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the economic headwinds, this an opportune time for companies to take action.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="26775ca2-cae5-4bc0-a695-2a0f7e7f8b57"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="26775ca2-cae5-4bc0-a695-2a0f7e7f8b57" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Aaron De Smet, Bonnie Dowling, Marino Mugayar-Baldocchi, and Bill Schaninger, <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/great-attrition-or-great-attraction-the-choice-is-yours">Great Attrition or Great Attraction? The choice is yours</a>, <em>McKinsey Quarterly</em>, September 8, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<h2>Companies can take advantage of postlockdown working trends to increase socioeconomic diversity in the workforce</h2>
<p>There are various means of increasing socioeconomic diversity in a companys workforce, including initiatives targeted at new or long-standing employees. Recruitment, the example explored here, is one place where most businesses could start their efforts.</p>
<p>Many companies have recruitment initiatives in place that aim to broaden racial and gender diversity within their workforces or industries. JPMorgan Chases Advancing Black Pathways initiative seeks to support and empower members of the Black community, including through summer fellowship programs at select offices.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="781d4ce1-93e0-4198-9796-87066d7c40a1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="781d4ce1-93e0-4198-9796-87066d7c40a1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Advancing Black Pathways Fellowship Program, JPMorgan Chase, accessed November 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Googles Generation Google scholarship program helps women studying computer science to excel in technology.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ee8b756c-a87c-4b35-81fe-6d028ca5e607"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ee8b756c-a87c-4b35-81fe-6d028ca5e607" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Google is offering scholarships to women studying computer science: Eligibility criteria, other details, Mint, November 8, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Similar approaches could be used to broaden socioeconomic diversity in the workplace, particularly ensuring that recruiting processes are meritocratic in that positions are filled by those most suited to perform them. There are seven potential actions to advance socioeconomic diversity that employers can explore.</p>
<ol>
    <li>
    <p><em>Consider a hybrid working model. </em>Many more people are working remotely since the pandemic, though there is ongoing debate regarding the extent to which this will endure. Only around a third of the workforce can reasonably perform their tasks remotely; for others, being physically near customers, colleagues, equipment, or specific premises is a necessary part of the job.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b67203ce-ba59-4fdd-8b47-ebb710af6ad3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b67203ce-ba59-4fdd-8b47-ebb710af6ad3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Susan Lund, Anu Madgavkar, James Manyika, and Sven Smit, <a href="/featured-insights/future-of-work/whats-next-for-remote-work-an-analysis-of-2000-tasks-800-jobs-and-nine-countries">Whats next for remote work: An analysis of 2,000 tasks, 800 jobs, and nine countries</a>, McKinsey Global Institute, November 23, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
    <p>However, remote working may be a model for supporting a more socioeconomically diverse workforce. Fewer days in the workplace may lead to a greater willingness to travel longer distances, which would in turn lead to lower commuting costs. This could also expand the effective labor market catchment area, putting the better-paid jobs in economic hubs within reach of those living in areas with historically lower economic activity, which suggests a 1.2 to 2.7 times increase in the labor catchment area (see sidebar How hybrid working could help promote socioeconomic diversity). However, as a general consideration for remote-working employees of any socioeconomic background, employers also need to watch out for potential biases (for example, in performance reviews) that may be exacerbated if face-to-face interactions become less frequent.</p>
    </li>
    <li><em>Widen the recruitment net</em> and consider ways to recruit from a wider array of educational or vocational institutions. Proximity is the single biggest factor for disadvantaged students in determining their choice of university, so those from lower socioeconomic backgrounds may be limited to the institutions they can access.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fb0cdcc1-c128-423e-8d1d-c095b26dd648"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fb0cdcc1-c128-423e-8d1d-c095b26dd648" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">S<em>tate of the nation 2017: Social mobility in Great Britain</em>, Social Mobility Commission, November 2017.</span></span></span></a></span> Another action companies could consider is where vocational hires and non-university candidates could deliver new roles and skills.</li>
    <li><em>Contextualize.</em> Socioeconomic background can affect the type of education available to a student as well as their likelihood of high achievement.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a8c4619a-b0dd-4c66-9be6-9bc6e209cafb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a8c4619a-b0dd-4c66-9be6-9bc6e209cafb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">See, for example, <em>State of the nation 2018-19: Social mobility in Great Britain</em>, Social Mobility Commission April 2019;  Paul Bolton, Susan Hubble, and Joe Lewis, <em>Equality of access and outcomes in higher education in England</em>, UK Parliament, House of Commons Library, June 2, 2021; Christine Farquharson, Sandra McNally, and Imran Tahir, Education inequalities, IFS Deaton Review, August 16, 2022; <em>Education in England: Annual report 2020</em>.</span></span></span></a></span> A-level contextualization platforms such as the REALrating or the Rare Contextual Recruitment System help recruiters to contextualize this information by taking applicants backgrounds into accounts when assessing applications. This can be recruiters starting point for understanding the diversity of the group of applicants and helping them to be more objective in evaluating candidate profiles.</li>
    <li><em>Monitor your recruitment funnel</em> to identify areas where you may be at risk of unintentionally excluding certain candidates based on their socioeconomic backgrounds. This may include reviewing screening criteria for interview biases or lack of accessibility to mock evaluation tests.</li>
    <li><em>Recruit with a view to upskilling.</em> The social restrictions during the COVID-19 pandemic led companies such as Cera and Amplify to address labor shortages by rapidly reskilling and redeploying individuals from sectors with sudden surplus labor.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2a8a9f91-14d1-4983-8360-25e63796c537"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2a8a9f91-14d1-4983-8360-25e63796c537" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Tera Allas, Will Fairbairn, and Elizabeth Foote, <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-economic-case-for-reskilling-in-the-uk-how-employers-can-thrive-by-boosting-workers-skills">The economic case for reskilling in the UK: How employers can thrive by boosting workers skills</a>, McKinsey, November 16, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> A reskilling or upskilling model like this offers the opportunity for employees from lower socioeconomic backgrounds to build new skills and increase value creation by entering into growing jobs (for example, application software developers) and also exit declining jobs (for example, those at risk because of automation).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="82aec260-c66e-43ad-9ed1-bd02278f9dde"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="82aec260-c66e-43ad-9ed1-bd02278f9dde" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Research by the Sutton Trust found that up to 15 million jobs could be at risk in the United Kingdom, the majority of which are held by those from middle and lower socioeconomic backgrounds. See Tom Cheshire, Rise of robots will shake the social ladder and could cost 15 million UK jobs, says report, Sky News, July 12, 2017.</span></span></span></a></span> The McKinsey Global Institutes <a href="/about-us/new-at-mckinsey-blog/where-the-jobs-are-insights-from-our-new-study">analysis on career pathways</a> showed that a cashier has the skill base that could enable them to transition with training into a sales management pathway and end up as a sales manager after three career moves, an occupation that is set to grow by 22 percent over the next decade and offers six times the median annual income of a cashier. The same reports analysis on the future of work after COVID-19 shows that almost all growth in labor demand by 2030 will occur in high-wage occupations.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d813e943-64c4-4b1f-90a3-f057cf5ff875"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">21</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d813e943-64c4-4b1f-90a3-f057cf5ff875" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="/featured-insights/future-of-work/the-future-of-work-after-covid-19">The future of work after COVID-19</a>, McKinsey Global Institute, February 18, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> </li>
    <li><em>Offer paid internships. </em>Unpaid internships can exclude those who dont have financial means, just as unadvertised or informally promoted internships can exclude those without professional connections. Remuneration and open advertisement can raise diversity in what is an important entry route into employment. Although this has a cost that not all businesses will be able to pay, for those that can, they may find that the larger talent pool attracted to the position supports the return on investment of other resources invested in the internship (for example, manager time).</li>
    <li><em>Track and report on progress. </em>Organizations may find it harder to change what they dont measure. Companies, therefore, could consider introducing social-mobility metrics such as free school meals and parental income or occupation to track the progress on socioeconomic diversity in their recruitment processes to support accountability. This is extremely sensitive information that must be handled with full adherence to data privacy legislation. When used appropriately and safely, the data could help to mitigate any inadvertent discrimination against those from more disadvantaged backgrounds. To this effect, the United Kingdoms Social Mobility Commission has published <a href="https://socialmobilityworks.org/toolkit/measurement/">a recommended tool kit</a> for employers, including a set of questions that applicants, and the workforce as a whole, could be asked.</li>
</ol>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Employers can monitor their recruitment funnel to identify areas where they may be at risk of unintentionally excluding certain candidates based on their socioeconomic backgrounds.</p></blockquote></div>
<hr>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>How hybrid working could help promote socioeconomic diversity</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>The proportion</strong> of the workforce who worked from home at some point in the United Kingdom rose from 27 percent in 2019 to 37 percent in 2020.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="efd57107-c820-41db-aa5c-18d1c87597f6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="efd57107-c820-41db-aa5c-18d1c87597f6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Business and individual attitudes towards the future of homeworking, UK: April to May 2021, UK Office for National Statistics, accessed November 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Some were working remotely all the time, but the majority divided their time between the home and the workplace.</p>
<p>As much of the UK economy is services oriented, data suggests it could support particularly high levels of remote working. According to the McKinsey Global Institute, an estimated 26 percent of UK employees could work from home effectively between three and five days a week, and a farther 22 percent between one and two days a week. This work-from-home potential is higher than it is in Germany, France, Japan, or the United States.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6efdb037-6340-4c47-a354-76b4d313837f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6efdb037-6340-4c47-a354-76b4d313837f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts/working-from-home-youre-still-in-the-minority">Working from home? Youre still in the minority</a>, McKinsey, December 2, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Moreover, enthusiasm for working at home appears to be high among employees. According to a Global Workplace Analytics survey of 3,000 office workers, those stating a preference to work 100 percent of the time from an office fell from 29 to 7 percent postpandemic.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e3cff0d6-8b3c-4831-a47e-3c70624e0c0c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e3cff0d6-8b3c-4831-a47e-3c70624e0c0c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Work From Home Experience Survey Results, Global Workplace Analytics, accessed November 2022. </span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>It is possible that employees would be prepared to travel farther to work under a hybrid model. The financial-services group HSBC, for example, estimates that an accountant who travels 20 miles every day to get to work would consider traveling 50 to 100 miles if going into the office was required only one or two days a week.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d4a7c128-48a2-4d49-892b-659dfa529185"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d4a7c128-48a2-4d49-892b-659dfa529185" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Matthew Lloyd et al., <em>Work from home and the staffers: Birth of a teratrend</em>, HSBC Global Research, September 16, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Such changes in commuting patterns could extend the catchment area of economic hubs. </p>
<p>New McKinsey research offers a high-level estimate of the impact of this trend, based on the UK governments travel-to-work areas (TTWAs). Designed to help understand commuting patterns, a TTWA is defined as one in which at least 75 percent of the people who work in the area also live in the area. Analytically, an average TTWA can be defined based on the behaviors of all workers, but it is also possible to outline TTWAs for subgroups of workers (for example, split by skill level of occupation or how people commute to work). Here, different groups have been used as a proxy for how much the average labor market might expand in a hybrid working world.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="699caf02-177d-444e-b198-39b9eaade6e6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="699caf02-177d-444e-b198-39b9eaade6e6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">There is an average TTWA based on the activity of all workers, and TTWAs for subgroups of workers, for example, different occupational skill levels or mode of commute. In this research, different groups are used as proxies for how much the average TTWA might expand in a hybrid working world. The lower figure in our range is the increase in the number of people between an average-skill TTWA and a high-skill TTWA, on the basis that remote working was higher among high-skill groups than the average pre-COVID-19. This is likely to be a conservative figure, however, as remote working was still relatively limited among the high skilled pre-COVID-19. The higher estimate is the difference between the standard TTWA and a TTWA encompassing those who travel by train to work. This figure is likely to be an overestimate; while many more will use more expensive, longer-range modes in a hybrid model (either train or longer car journeys), not everyone will be able or willing to do so.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>The research estimates that between 1.2 and 2.7 times more people would fall within the catchment area of four prosperous cities under a hybrid working model in which people would be prepared or could afford to take jobs farther away from home (exhibit). The map of Wales shown below illustrates that the TTWA could extend from Cardiff into areas of significantly lower GDP. Secondary factors could also make this a particularly powerful enablerfor example, carers (31 percent of whom reported struggling financially in a 2021 survey)<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e6ed63cb-7607-432d-95bc-f2d94c67f690"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e6ed63cb-7607-432d-95bc-f2d94c67f690" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>State of caring 2021 report: A snapshot of unpaid care in the UK</em>, Carers UK, November 3, 2021. Carers are defined in the report as those providing unpaid care to an older, disabled, or ill relative or friend (excludes nondisabled children).</span></span></span></a></span> may be unable to relocate to more prosperous economic hubs for 100 percent in-person jobs but may consider such positions with hybrid working arrangements without needing to relocate.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit </span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/fixing%20the%20ladder%20how%20uk%20businesses%20benefit%20from%20better%20social%20mobility/svgz-fixingtheladder-ex2-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Through hybrid working, companies could help connect 1.2 to 2.5 times more people to prosperous economic hubs." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/fixing%20the%20ladder%20how%20uk%20businesses%20benefit%20from%20better%20social%20mobility/svgz-fixingtheladder-ex2-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The circumstances into which individuals are born have a strong influence on their life opportunitiesan influence that may have been accentuated during the COVID-19 pandemic. At the same time, the reconsideration of working norms coming out of the lockdown may create tailwinds for businesses that adapt their recruitment models.</p>
<p>The business case for diversity, equity, and inclusion is <a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/diversity-wins-how-inclusion-matters">stronger than ever</a>. A strong proposition in all of the ESG factors can help companies attract and retain quality employees, enhance employee motivation by instilling a sense of purpose, and increase productivity overall. Widening access to a more diverse socioeconomic workforce can also more broadly influence economic growth and productivity of a nation.</p>
<p>Employee satisfaction is positively correlated with shareholder returns. The London Business Schools Alex Edmans found that the companies that made Fortunes 100 Best Companies to Work For list generated 2.3 to 3.8 percent higher stock returns per year than their peers over a more than 25-year horizon. Moreover, it has long been observed that employees with a sense not just of satisfaction but also of connection perform better. Widening socioeconomic diversity, just like diversity in gender and ethnicity, can help organizations perform better by sourcing from all available talent and matching them to high-value jobs. Their businesses, the economy, and wider society all stand to benefit from a more socially mobile world.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong>Peter Cooper</strong> is an associate partner in McKinseys London office, where <strong><a href="/our-people/alastair-hamilton">Alastair Hamilton</a></strong> and <strong><a href="/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b71c8f4ee-2e6d-4b9b-af5c-bba761451573%7d%40en">Colin Shaw</a></strong> are partners and <strong>Liberty York</strong> is a knowledge expert.</p>
<p>The authors wish to thank Tera Allas, Taylor Burns, Emily Capstick, Gagan Khurana, Alice Lassman, Lola Olaore, and Jali Packer for their contributions to this article. </p></div></div></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 mck-u-screen-only"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-5
