type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Fixing the ladder How UK businesses benefit from better social mobility","displayName":"Fixing the ladder How UK businesses benefit from better social mobility","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"dcdb34d9-f376-4481-9006-84abe7d22d48","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Fixing the ladder: How UK businesses benefit from better social mobility"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"How UK businesses can benefit from social mobility"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Socioeconomic diversity merits consideration alongside gender, race, ethnicity, and other diversity dimensions on the UK corporate agenda."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"In this article, we look at why UK businesses should consider socioeconomic diversity and social mobility when it comes to hiring practices."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-01-25T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]] [[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSocial mobility\u003c/strong\u003e is a concept that considers people\u0026rsquo;s socioeconomic circumstances and the degree to which they change over a lifetime and across generations. This includes a consideration of whether a person\u0026rsquo;s social and economic future is shaped by where they start in life. In a society with high social mobility, someone could, for example, be born to economically disadvantaged parents but still have the same likelihood of opportunities as someone born into a more prosperous home.[[Footnote 1]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eBusinesses with strong environmental, social, and governance (ESG) motivations are increasingly looking at how they can promote diversity, equity, and inclusion as part of their \u0026ldquo;S,\u0026rdquo; or \u003cem\u003esocial\u003c/em\u003e, agenda.  However, socioeconomic diversity, which is directly linked to social mobility, is a diversity category that many businesses struggle to define and ultimately engage in. It is complex, dynamic, multidimensional, and contextual to a given country. It is also intersectional: socioeconomic factors can combine with gender, race, ethnicity, and other factors in a way that exacerbates the disadvantages experienced by people in those groups.[[Footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis article will examine some of the economic and business benefits that companies can expect from helping to broaden the socioeconomic diversity of the talent pool in their organizations. Some of these benefits are macro at the economy level and can be measured: better social mobility can support economic growth through more effective deployment of talent. Others are micro at the company level and, given that socioeconomic data is currently hard to collect, can be inferred from broader data on diversity: research shows that organizations with higher rates of diversity in their workforce perform better for reasons that include being better able to attract top talent and improved customer orientation, employee satisfaction, and decision making.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCorporations now have a critical window of opportunity to reflect on socioeconomic diversity. Our research indicates that the current economic and societal shocks, such as the COVID-19 pandemic and the rapidly increasing cost of living, have affected socioeconomic disadvantages and social mobility, with knock-on effects for employees, candidates, suppliers, customers, and communities in real time. At the same time, many people management processes will need to be reconsidered in response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the economic headwinds, making this an opportune time for corporations to consider which actions they can take next.[[Footnote 3]] \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile social mobility is first and foremost influenced by public policy, corporations can also take action\u0026mdash;and benefit from it. There are many interventions, but this article presents those in one area where companies could start: recruitment. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eLow social mobility comes at a cost to the economy\u0026mdash;and to individual companies\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eThere are ethical arguments for social mobility, but in this article we focus on the economic arguments. Social mobility affects both national economic performance and the financial performance of individual companies. Understanding the context and effects of social mobility is important for business leaders who wish to understand and maximize socioeconomic diversity in their own organizations (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;The long-term impacts of socioeconomic disadvantage on individuals in the United Kingdom\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eThe loss to the economy\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs an economic principle, the more efficient an economy is at matching job positions to those with the greatest potential to perform them well, the higher the economic output per person.[[Footnote 4]] Low social mobility is therefore likely to affect both employment and productivity: those from a disadvantaged background may not have access to the opportunities to use their capabilities and skills to the fullest. This hampers value creation or, as the World Economic Forum noted in its 2020 report on global social mobility, \u0026ldquo;Anything that undermines the best allocation of talent and impedes the accumulation of human capital may significantly hamper growth.\u0026rdquo;[[Footnote 5]] \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe Sutton Trust, a UK charity that works to promote social mobility,[[Footnote 6]] has put a figure on the economic impact of the United Kingdom having social-mobility levels that are lower than the regional average (exhibit). A 2017 study found that a modest increase in the United Kingdom\u0026rsquo;s social mobility (to the average level across Western Europe) could be associated with about a 9 percent increase in GDP, equivalent to \u0026pound;2,620 per person, or \u0026pound;170 billion, to the UK economy annually (in 2016 prices).[[Footnote 7]] The opportunity for the UK economy may have increased following the economic and societal shocks of COVID-19 and the rapidly increasing cost of living (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Social mobility in the United Kingdom since 2020\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003ch3\u003eThe opportunity for companies\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJust as low social mobility can constrain economic growth as a result of inefficient talent allocation, so too could it constrain corporate performance. Like gender and ethnicity, it is a diversity issue, with significant intersectionality.[[Footnote 8]]  \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s \u003cem\u003eDiversity wins\u003c/em\u003e report showed a correlation between performance and diversity in companies around the world.[[Footnote 9]] Those in the top quartile in terms of gender diversity on executive teams were 25 percent more likely to earn above-average profits than those in the bottom quartile. In the case of ethnic and cultural diversity, this gap increased to 36 percent. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/why-diversity-matters\"\u003eOur research\u003c/a\u003e suggests that diverse companies may be able to outperform because they recruit from the widest pool of talent and, in doing so, improve customer orientation, employee satisfaction, and decision making, all of which lead to a virtuous cycle of better performance. Although there is still significant work to be done, data on gender and ethnicity has often been collected and monitored by many larger organizations for years, making it somewhat easier for companies to see where to take action on diversity on these dimensions. With socioeconomic diversity, however, the picture is more complex for three reasons. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFirst, there is no single indicator of an individual\u0026rsquo;s socioeconomic background. Analysis may use one or multiple indicators, including the postcode where someone grew up, if they received free school meals, if they were the first generation in their family to go to university, or what the occupation of their parents or caregivers were when they were 14 years old. Each of these indicators has its advantages and limitations. Second, socioeconomic status is not binary. Everyone grows up somewhere on a scale from the most deprived through to the wealthiest. Finally, this information is private, and each individual would need to consent to sharing it. Not everyone wants to self-identify as coming from a certain socioeconomic background. Therefore, most organizations, no matter how much they desire to support social mobility, do not always have the base information to be able to understand or make decisions to broaden the socioeconomic level of their talent pool. These complexities notwithstanding, there is substantive evidence that a number of UK professions are far from being socioeconomically diverse based on a number of common socioeconomic diversity metrics.[[Footnote 10]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis is where understanding the context of social mobility can help to identify opportunity areas. For example, socioeconomic background is one factor in educational achievement: children from economically disadvantaged families tend to do less well at school and have less access to highly rated institutions than children from more prosperous households.[[Footnote 11]] Positions and sectors that recruit primarily based on academic attainment are therefore less likely to be attuned to the nuances of socioeconomically diverse backgrounds, and in the search for talent, may be missing out on candidates who have high potential across other metrics.[[Footnote 12]] \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith many corporations reconsidering their people management processes in response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the economic headwinds, this an opportune time for companies to take action.[[Footnote 13]] \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCompanies can take advantage of postlockdown working trends to increase socioeconomic diversity in the workforce\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are various means of increasing socioeconomic diversity in a company\u0026rsquo;s workforce, including initiatives targeted at new or long-standing employees. Recruitment, the example explored here, is one place where most businesses could start their efforts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMany companies have recruitment initiatives in place that aim to broaden racial and gender diversity within their workforces or industries. JPMorgan Chase\u0026rsquo;s Advancing Black Pathways initiative seeks to support and empower members of the Black community, including through summer fellowship programs at select offices.[[Footnote 14]] Google\u0026rsquo;s Generation Google scholarship program helps women studying computer science to excel in technology.[[Footnote 15]] Similar approaches could be used to broaden socioeconomic diversity in the workplace, particularly ensuring that recruiting processes are meritocratic in that positions are filled by those most suited to perform them. There are seven potential actions to advance socioeconomic diversity that employers can explore.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eConsider a hybrid working model. \u003c/em\u003eMany more people are working remotely since the pandemic, though there is ongoing debate regarding the extent to which this will endure. Only around a third of the workforce can reasonably perform their tasks remotely; for others, being physically near customers, colleagues, equipment, or specific premises is a necessary part of the job.[[Footnote 16]]\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eHowever, remote working may be a model for supporting a more socioeconomically diverse workforce. Fewer days in the workplace may lead to a greater willingness to travel longer distances, which would in turn lead to lower commuting costs. This could also expand the effective labor market catchment area, putting the better-paid jobs in economic hubs within reach of those living in areas with historically lower economic activity, which suggests a 1.2 to 2.7 times increase in the labor catchment area (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;How hybrid working could help promote socioeconomic diversity\u0026rdquo;). However, as a general consideration for remote-working employees of any socioeconomic background, employers also need to watch out for potential biases (for example, in performance reviews) that may be exacerbated if face-to-face interactions become less frequent.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eWiden the recruitment net\u003c/em\u003e and consider ways to recruit from a wider array of educational or vocational institutions. Proximity is the single biggest factor for disadvantaged students in determining their choice of university, so those from lower socioeconomic backgrounds may be limited to the institutions they can access.[[Footnote 17]] Another action companies could consider is where vocational hires and non-university candidates could deliver new roles and skills.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eContextualize.\u003c/em\u003e Socioeconomic background can affect the type of education available to a student as well as their likelihood of high achievement.[[Footnote 18]] A-level contextualization platforms such as the REALrating or the Rare Contextual Recruitment System help recruiters to contextualize this information by taking applicants\u0026rsquo; backgrounds into accounts when assessing applications. This can be recruiters\u0026rsquo; starting point for understanding the diversity of the group of applicants and helping them to be more objective in evaluating candidate profiles.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eMonitor your recruitment funnel\u003c/em\u003e to identify areas where you may be at risk of unintentionally excluding certain candidates based on their socioeconomic backgrounds. This may include reviewing screening criteria for interview biases or lack of accessibility to mock evaluation tests.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eRecruit with a view to upskilling.\u003c/em\u003e The social restrictions during the COVID-19 pandemic led companies such as Cera and Amplify to address labor shortages by rapidly reskilling and redeploying individuals from sectors with sudden surplus labor.[[Footnote 19]] A reskilling or upskilling model like this offers the opportunity for employees from lower socioeconomic backgrounds to build new skills and increase value creation by entering into growing jobs (for example, application software developers) and also exit declining jobs (for example, those at risk because of automation).[[Footnote 20]] The McKinsey Global Institute\u0026rsquo;s \u003ca href=\"/about-us/new-at-mckinsey-blog/where-the-jobs-are-insights-from-our-new-study\"\u003eanalysis on career pathways\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;showed that a cashier has the skill base that could enable them to transition with training into a sales management pathway and end up as a sales manager after three career moves, an occupation that is set to grow by 22 percent over the next decade and offers six times the median annual income of a cashier. The same report\u0026rsquo;s analysis on the future of work after COVID-19 shows that almost all growth in labor demand by 2030 will occur in high-wage occupations.[[Footnote 21]] \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eOffer paid internships. \u003c/em\u003eUnpaid internships can exclude those who don\u0026rsquo;t have financial means, just as unadvertised or informally promoted internships can exclude those without professional connections. Remuneration and open advertisement can raise diversity in what is an important entry route into employment. Although this has a cost that not all businesses will be able to pay, for those that can, they may find that the larger talent pool attracted to the position supports the return on investment of other resources invested in the internship (for example, manager time).\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTrack and report on progress. \u003c/em\u003eOrganizations may find it harder to change what they don\u0026rsquo;t measure. Companies, therefore, could consider introducing social-mobility metrics such as free school meals and parental income or occupation to track the progress on socioeconomic diversity in their recruitment processes to support accountability. This is extremely sensitive information that must be handled with full adherence to data privacy legislation. When used appropriately and safely, the data could help to mitigate any inadvertent discrimination against those from more disadvantaged backgrounds. To this effect, the United Kingdom\u0026rsquo;s Social Mobility Commission has published \u003ca href=\"https://socialmobilityworks.org/toolkit/measurement/\"\u003ea recommended tool kit\u003c/a\u003e for employers, including a set of questions that applicants, and the workforce as a whole, could be asked.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n[[PullQuote 1]]\n\u003chr /\u003e\n[[Sidebar 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe circumstances into which individuals are born have a strong influence on their life opportunities\u0026mdash;an influence that may have been accentuated during the COVID-19 pandemic. At the same time, the reconsideration of working norms coming out of the lockdown may create tailwinds for businesses that adapt their recruitment models.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe business case for diversity, equity, and inclusion is \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/diversity-wins-how-inclusion-matters\"\u003estronger than ever\u003c/a\u003e. A strong proposition in all of the ESG factors can help companies attract and retain quality employees, enhance employee motivation by instilling a sense of purpose, and increase productivity overall. Widening access to a more diverse socioeconomic workforce can also more broadly influence economic growth and productivity of a nation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEmployee satisfaction is positively correlated with shareholder returns. The London Business School\u0026rsquo;s Alex Edmans found that the companies that made Fortune\u0026rsquo;s \u0026ldquo;100 Best Companies to Work For\u0026rdquo; list generated 2.3 to 3.8 percent higher stock returns per year than their peers over a more than 25-year horizon. Moreover, it has long been observed that employees with a sense not just of satisfaction but also of connection perform better. Widening socioeconomic diversity, just like diversity in gender and ethnicity, can help organizations perform better by sourcing from all available talent and matching them to high-value jobs. Their businesses, the economy, and wider society all stand to benefit from a more socially mobile world.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-01-25T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eIndividuals can be both upwardly and downwardly mobile. current on your favorite topics"}}}]},"articlesidebar":{"results":[{"mediaID":{"value":"1"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe United Kingdom\u0026rsquo;s social-mobility\u003c/strong\u003e context has considerable complexity beyond what is explored in this article. What follows is a summary of existing data and research that may be useful context for businesses.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEvidence suggests that being born into a low-income family can affect many aspects of a person\u0026rsquo;s later life\u0026mdash;their health, their education, their earnings, and their children\u0026rsquo;s prospects across these same dimensions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy the time individuals enter the workforce, they have already been significantly shaped by their socioeconomic backgrounds. Children born to parents with low incomes are more likely to experience poor nutrition, chronic disease, and mental-health problems throughout their lives as a consequence of their families being less able to provide them with healthy food, good-quality housing, adequate heating, or social and cultural opportunities.[[Footnote 1]] Children in lower-income neighborhoods are less likely to have access to highly rated schools, and the economically disadvantaged tend to do less well at school.[[Footnote 2]] Students from socioeconomically disadvantaged backgrounds are also more likely to drop out of university and less likely to achieve a first- or upper-second-class degree than those from more advantaged backgrounds.[[Footnote 3]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs reported by the UK government\u0026rsquo;s Social Mobility Commission, people of low-income upbringing are more likely to experience unemployment and more likely to remain in low-paid employment.[[Footnote 4]] A study by Sam Friedman and Daniel Laurison, sociology professors at the London School of Economics, found that those in high-status occupations whose parents were employed in semiroutine and routine jobs earned, on average, \u0026pound;6,200 a year less than colleagues in the same occupations, but whose parents had higher professional and managerial backgrounds. This remained the case even after controlling for a host of factors such as educational qualification, ethnicity, and different wage levels in different regions.[[Footnote 5]] \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAll ethnicities and genders can experience socioeconomic disadvantage, but socioeconomic disadvantages can also be compounded by one\u0026rsquo;s gender and ethnicity.[[Footnote 6]] For example, the Social Mobility Commission\u0026rsquo;s 2016 report \u003cem\u003eEthnicity, gender and social mobility\u003c/em\u003e found that socioeconomically disadvantaged \u0026ldquo;White British\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;White Other\u0026rdquo; pupils were the lowest-performing groups at primary and secondary school and that Black children were the group most likely to grow up in poverty and one of the least likely groups to achieve a first- or upper-second-class degree at university.[[Footnote 7]] When analyzed alongside dimensions such as gender and ethnicity, socioeconomic background can provide a deeper understanding of where disadvantage arises: for example, female students outnumber male students in higher education in the United Kingdom,[[Footnote 8]] yet government analysis shows that disadvantaged young women are the most likely group to choose post-16 technical courses which lead to lower paid jobs.[[Footnote 9]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eData suggests that perceptions of the United Kindom\u0026rsquo;s level of social mobility are also shifting. According to a 2019 survey conducted by the Sutton Trust, a UK charity that works to promote social mobility,[[Footnote 10]] 35 percent of respondents agreed that people have equal opportunities to get ahead, a drop from 53 percent in 2008.[[Footnote 11]]\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The long-term impacts of socioeconomic disadvantage on individuals in the United Kingdom"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eChild poverty in Scotland: Health impact and health inequalities\u003c/em\u003e, NHS Heath Scotland, 2018.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAvinash Akhal, Jo Hutchinson, and  Mary Ready, \u003cem\u003eEducation in England: Annual report 2020\u003c/em\u003e, Education Policy Institute, August 26, 2020.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eSue Hubble, Paul Bolton, and Joe Lewis, \u0026ldquo;Equality of access and outcomes in higher education in England,\u0026rdquo; House of Commons Library, June 2, 2021.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eLearning ladders: The role of adult training in supporting progression from low pay\u003c/em\u003e, Social Mobility Commission, November 2020.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBritish Politics and Policy\u003c/em\u003e, \u0026ldquo;Introducing the \u0026lsquo;class\u0026rsquo; ceiling,\u0026rdquo; blog post by Sam Friedman and Daniel Laurison, March 31, 2015.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eSocial mobility is a highly intersectional topic. Other aspects of experience including sexual orientation and disability are also likely to affect a person\u0026rsquo;s opportunities to be socially mobile. See Kerith Conron, Shoshana  Goldberg, and Carolyn Halpern, \u0026ldquo;Sexual orientation and sex differences in socioeconomic status: A population-based investigation in the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent to Adult Health,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eJournal of Epidemiology and Community Health\u003c/em\u003e, November 2018, Volume 72; Jouja Maamri and Daniel Dipper, \u0026ldquo;No two journeys: Disability,\u0026rdquo; Sutton Trust, January 19, 2021.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eEleanor Bernardes et al., \u003cem\u003eEthnicity, gender, and social mobility\u003c/em\u003e, Social Mobility Commission, December 28, 2016.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eRachel Hewitt, \u0026ldquo;Mind the gap: Gender differences in higher education,\u0026rdquo; Higher Education Policy Institute, March 7, 2020.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Disadvantaged women face pay penalty due to their subject choice,\u0026rdquo; Social Mobility Commission press release, March 30, 2021.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMcKinsey is one of four consultancy firms that have collaborated with the Sutton Trust to create a new \u0026ldquo;Pathways to Consulting\u0026rdquo; program to help improve socioeconomic diversity in the consulting workforce.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eSocial mobility polling 2019, Sutton Trust, November 20, 2019.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"2"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEconomic and societal shocks\u003c/strong\u003e such as COVID-19 and the rapidly increasing cost of living can aggravate existing socioeconomic disadvantages and restrict social mobility.[[Footnote 1]] These conditions have knock-on effects for employees, candidates, suppliers, customers, and communities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTwo observations indicate that social mobility in the United Kingdom is likely to have worsened since the pandemic. First, data shows that those in lower socioeconomic groups were affected harder in areas such as health,[[Footnote 2]] employment,[[Footnote 3]] and financial security[[Footnote 4]] during the height of the pandemic and lockdowns. Education, a key enabler of social mobility, was interrupted at all levels, from nursery school through to university. On average, students globally are eight months behind where they would have been absent the pandemic.[[Footnote 5]] A Department for Education review in 2021 found that pupils in the United Kingdom from lower-income backgrounds suffered greater learning losses than those from higher-income families.[[Footnote 6]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSecond, data shows that these same groups are likely to struggle in the economic environment that has existed since the pandemic. Current inflationary conditions are disproportionately affecting low-income households,[[Footnote 7]] and gas and electricity costs make up a much higher proportion of these households\u0026rsquo; total expenditures.[[Footnote 8]] The Resolution Foundation, a think tank focused on improving the living standards of those with low to middle incomes in the United Kingdom, estimates that prior to the pandemic 1.3 million families had no savings to cope with unexpected expenses or rising costs. Since then, lower-income households were less likely to increase savings during the pandemic than higher-income ones and have fewer resources from which to rebuild in the current climate.[[Footnote 9]]\n\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Social mobility in the United Kingdom since 2020"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eJonathan Bridges, Georgina Green, and Mark Joy, \u0026ldquo;Credit, crises, and inequality,\u0026rdquo; Bank Underground, May 3, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFor example, analysis by the Office for National Statistics of deaths between March and April 2020, when the virus first had impact at scale, shows that those who died with a confirmed case of the SARS-CoV-2 virus were more likely to be economically disadvantaged. See \u003cem\u003eDisparities in the risk and outcomes of COVID-19\u003c/em\u003e, Public Health England, August 2020.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFor example, according to the Resolution Foundation, 18 percent of parents from the bottom quintile of income distribution lost a job between April 2020 and March 2021, almost double the rate among parents in the rest of the population. See Andrew Eyles, S\u003cem\u003eocial mobility in the time of COVID: Assessing the social mobility implications of COVID-19\u003c/em\u003e, Economy 2030 Inquiry, December 2021.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFor example, Resolution Foundation analysis found that poorer households were far more likely to have depleted their savings and increased their debt than higher-income groups during the first year of the pandemic. See Torsten Bell, \u0026ldquo;The COVID certainty: More savings for the rich, more debt for the poor,\u0026rdquo; Resolution Foundation, June 30, 2021.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/education/our-insights/how-covid-19-caused-a-global-learning-crisis\"\u003eHow COVID-19 caused a global learning crisis\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; McKinsey, April 4, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eUnderstanding progress in the 2020/21 academic year\u003c/em\u003e, Department for Education and Renaissance Learning, Education Policy Institute, October 2021. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMolly Broome and Jack Leslie, \u003cem\u003eArrears fears: The distribution of UK household wealth and the impact on families\u003c/em\u003e, Resolution Foundation, July 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eKarl Handscomb and Jonathan Marshall, \u003cem\u003eCutting back to keep warm\u003c/em\u003e, Resolution Foundation, August 15, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;1.3 million families\u0026mdash;including one-in-twelve poor families\u0026mdash;have no savings to cope with rising cost pressures or unexpected expenses,\u0026rdquo; Resolution Foundation, July 17, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"3"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe proportion\u003c/strong\u003e of the workforce who worked from home at some point in the United Kingdom rose from 27 percent in 2019 to 37 percent in 2020.[[Footnote 1]] Some were working remotely all the time, but the majority divided their time between the home and the workplace.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs much of the UK economy is services oriented, data suggests it could support particularly high levels of remote working. According to the McKinsey Global Institute, an estimated 26 percent of UK employees could work from home effectively between three and five days a week, and a farther 22 percent between one and two days a week. This work-from-home potential is higher than it is in Germany, France, Japan, or the United States.[[Footnote 2]] Moreover, enthusiasm for working at home appears to be high among employees. According to a Global Workplace Analytics survey of 3,000 office workers, those stating a preference to work 100 percent of the time from an office fell from 29 to 7 percent postpandemic.[[Footnote 3]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt is possible that employees would be prepared to travel farther to work under a hybrid model. The financial-services group HSBC, for example, estimates that an accountant who travels 20 miles every day to get to work would consider traveling 50 to 100 miles if going into the office was required only one or two days a week.[[Footnote 4]] Such changes in commuting patterns could extend the catchment area of economic hubs. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNew McKinsey research offers a high-level estimate of the impact of this trend, based on the UK government\u0026rsquo;s travel-to-work areas (TTWAs). Designed to help understand commuting patterns, a TTWA is defined as one in which at least 75 percent of the people who work in the area also live in the area. Analytically, an average TTWA can be defined based on the behaviors of all workers, but it is also possible to outline TTWAs for subgroups of workers (for example, split by skill level of occupation or how people commute to work). Here, different groups have been used as a proxy for how much the average labor market might expand in a hybrid working world.[[Footnote 5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe research estimates that between 1.2 and 2.7 times more people would fall within the catchment area of four prosperous cities under a hybrid working model in which people would be prepared or could afford to take jobs farther away from home (exhibit). The map of Wales shown below illustrates that the TTWA could extend from Cardiff into areas of significantly lower GDP. Secondary factors could also make this a particularly powerful enabler\u0026mdash;for example, carers (31 percent of whom reported struggling financially in a 2021 survey)[[Footnote 6]] may be unable to relocate to more prosperous economic hubs for 100 percent in-person jobs but may consider such positions with hybrid working arrangements without needing to relocate.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"How hybrid working could help promote socioeconomic diversity"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Business and individual attitudes towards the future of homeworking, UK: April to May 2021,\u0026rdquo; UK Office for National Statistics, accessed November 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts/working-from-home-youre-still-in-the-minority\"\u003eWorking from home? You\u0026rsquo;re still in the minority\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; McKinsey, December 2, 2020.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eWork From Home Experience Survey Results, Global Workplace Analytics, accessed November 2022. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMatthew Lloyd et al., \u003cem\u003eWork from home and the staffers: Birth of a teratrend\u003c/em\u003e, HSBC Global Research, September 16, 2020.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThere is an average TTWA based on the activity of all workers, and TTWAs for subgroups of workers, for example, different occupational skill levels or mode of commute. In this research, different groups are used as proxies for how much the average TTWA might expand in a hybrid working world. The lower figure in our range is the increase in the number of people between an average-skill TTWA and a high-skill TTWA, on the basis that remote working was higher among high-skill groups than the average pre-COVID-19. This is likely to be a conservative figure, however, as remote working was still relatively limited among the high skilled pre-COVID-19. The higher estimate is the difference between the standard TTWA and a TTWA encompassing those who travel by train to work. This figure is likely to be an overestimate; while many more will use more expensive, longer-range modes in a hybrid model (either train or longer car journeys), not everyone will be able or willing to do so.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eState of caring 2021 report: A snapshot of unpaid care in the UK\u003c/em\u003e, Carers UK, November 3, 2021.
